dublinCore.dc:title: 119 S1872 RS: Critical Infrastructure Manufacturing Feasibility Act
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Ms. Ernst (for herself and Ms. Blunt Rochester) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation
Reported by Mr. Cruz, with an amendment
action.action-instruction: Strike out all after the enacting clause and insert the part printed in italic

form.official-title: To direct the Secretary of Commerce to conduct a study on the feasibility of manufacturing in the United States products for critical infrastructure sectors, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Critical Infrastructure Manufacturing Feasibility Act.

section.header: Study on critical infrastructure manufacturing in the United States

subsection.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Commerce shall conduct a study to—

paragraph.text: identify, within each critical infrastructure sector, any product that is in high demand and is being imported due to a manufacturing, material, or supply chain constraint in the United States;
analyze the costs and benefits of manufacturing in the United States any product identified under paragraph (1), including any effects on—

subparagraph.text: jobs, employment rates, and labor conditions in the United States; and

paragraph.text: identify any product identified under paragraph (1) that feasibly may be manufactured in the United States; and
analyze the feasibility of, and any impediments to, manufacturing any product identified under paragraph (3) in—

subparagraph.text: an industrial park in a rural area.

subsection.text: Not later than 18 months after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall—

paragraph.text: submit to Congress a report containing the results of the study required by subsection (a), with recommendations relating to manufacturing in the United States products identified under subsection (a)(3); and
make the report available to the public on the website of the Department of Commerce.

subsection.text: This section may not be construed to provide the Secretary of Commerce with authority to compel a person to provide information described in this section.

In this section, the term critical infrastructure sector means each of the 16 designated critical infrastructure sectors identified in Presidential Policy Directive 21 of February 12, 2013 (Critical Infrastructure Security and Resilience).

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Critical Infrastructure Manufacturing Feasibility Act.

section.header: Study on critical infrastructure manufacturing in the United States

subsection.text: In this section, the term critical infrastructure sector means each of the 16 designated critical infrastructure sectors identified in Presidential Policy Directive 21 of February 12, 2013 entitled Critical Infrastructure Security and Resilience.
Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Commerce shall conduct a study to—

paragraph.text: identify, within each critical infrastructure sector, any product—

subparagraph.text: necessary for the construction, maintenance, operation, or restoration of the critical infrastructure sector; and
that is in high demand and is being imported due to a manufacturing, material, or supply chain constraint in the United States;

paragraph.text: analyze the costs and benefits of manufacturing in the United States any product identified under paragraph (1), including any effects on—

subparagraph.text: jobs, employment rates, and labor conditions in the United States; and

paragraph.text: identify any product identified under paragraph (1) that feasibly may be manufactured in the United States;
analyze the feasibility of, and any impediments to, manufacturing any product identified under paragraph (3) in—

subparagraph.text: an industrial park in a rural area; and

paragraph.text: identify any Federal policies, regulations, or guidance in effect that may inhibit, create barriers to, or increase the cost of manufacturing a product identified under paragraph (1) in the United States.

subsection.text: Not later than 18 months after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Commerce shall—

paragraph.text: submit to Congress an unclassified report, which may include a classified annex, containing the results of the study required by subsection (b), with recommendations relating to manufacturing in the United States products identified under subsection (b)(3); and
make the unclassified report available to the public on the website of the Department of Commerce.

subsection.text: This section may not be construed to provide the Secretary of Commerce with authority to compel a person to provide information described in this section.
